resources.string:
This is a simple 
 'Hello World' 
 application that I have created using my small knowledge about programming. 
 Also, I used three books, a lot of Internet resources and five or six HOWTO tutorials. Maybe this application is not the most useful in the world, but it shows basics that can be used in android programs. 
 Before I begun to write this program, I did not know anything about Java, XML or developing for android at all. So, in this application are present five java classes, and six layouts, three sounds, also there are three buttons: two in main menu and one in the text generator (actually info is not true, there were significant changes ;-) ). 
 Well, you can press all button that you see.
This is a simple \n \'Hello World\' \n application, which was created just for fun.
There are following features available in this app:
Time from SW start in ms:
Time elapsed from boot in ms:

This is a Stopwatch that can be used for precise time measurments.
 1. Time output: it has 'HhH:MM:SS:msms' format to show time.
 2. Current time: biggest digits. hours, minutes, seconds - green color; millisecond - red color.
 3. Buttons:
 Catch - catch current time snapshot.
 Start - begin/resume time measurement cycle.
 Reset - set current time measurement cycle to zero.
 Stop - stop/pause current time cycle.
 Clear - clear all cycles and measures.

Here is more advanced help info and some tips and tricks…
 
 As you see, except buttons and current time cycle there are more objects:
 Current time check - it is the last time notch, caught by pressing 'Catch' button.
 '––:––:––:–––' - there are nine fields, where your time snapshots can be stored.

Time from SW start in ms: means time elapsed from launching actually 'stopwatch' activity in milliseconds.
 Time from SW start formatted: means the same, but now it is in 'Hh:Mm:Ss:msms' format.
 Time elapsed from boot in ms: means time elapsed from booting your device in milliseconds. 
 Time elapsed from boot formatted: means, again, the same, but now it is in 'Hh:Mm:Ss:msms' format.
 At the end, there is a digital clock, that shows current system time.

After you starting measure cycle you can catch time snapshots. These snapshots are stored in a specific format that can be useful in certain situations.
 1st digit - number of a field
 2nd - current countdown
 3rd - number of time snapshot.

 For example, you need to measure time, that will spent 5 different person to perform five different actions and 3 times for 6th person:
 click Clear, then for first 5 actions click Start -> Catch -> Stop -> Reset -> Start every time, and then Stop -> Reset -> Start and press Catch 3 times to measure 3 cycles for 6th person.
There are nine fields where time measurements are saved, also Current time check field displays last time notch of current cycle and stores it till Catch button is pressed again.
I know that it looks confusing at first time, but when you deal with it, you will be able perform quite complex time measurements :-).\n

string.name: what_it_can_do_sw_ad_further_info_str
string.i: I hope it will be funny and challenging for you…
